info.name: Stedi Starter Pack
info.description:
A collection of Stedi API requests you can use to work with EDI Core. Each API request comes with an example request and response. We have two example request included:

*   Convert a EDI document to JSON EDI (JEDI)
*   Convert a JSON EDI (JEDI) document to EDI
    

Both examples are populated with sample data so you can easily try a request. You can try to do a conversion using your own documents using this collection too.

## Getting started

1.  [Create or login to your Stedi account](https://terminal.stedi.com/sign-up) using Terminal.
2.  [Create an API Key](https://www.stedi.com/docs/authentication) in Terminal.
3.  Set the Postman environment variable `stediApiKey` with your API key. If you plan to use Stedi mappings, set the `stediMappingId` as well.
4.  You can now send API requests to Stedi by pressing "send request".

item.name: EDI Core

request.description:
Translate between supported EDI formats (JSON and EDI X12)

Review the *body* of POST call for guidance on how to use fields. If you have a specific use case in mind, go to examples where you'll find how to:

*   translate EDI to JEDI (JSON EDI)
*   translate JSON to EDI
*   translate and validate against a specific mapping guide
    

**Notes**

*   it's okay if your EDI files contain `\n` LF or `\r\n` CLRF, they will parse successfully. Check out our detailed instructions on how to format EDI file for Postman call [here](https://github.com/Stedi/api-starter-pack/tree/main/postman-collections-for-import).
*   browse our library of [EDI mapping guides](https://edi.stedi.com/mapping-guides) and use the guide version ID to validate EDI via the API

response.name: error validation w. Mapping Guide
validation w. Mapping Guide

item.description: Take a look at the EDI Core API [guide](https://www.stedi.com/docs/edi-core) and [API reference](https://www.stedi.com/docs/api/edi-core) for more details.
